newsitem.title: UK: Worldwide Advertising & Media Digest - April 1.
newsitem.headline: Worldwide Advertising & Media Digest - April 1.

text.p: ....REUTERS WORLDWIDE ADVERTISING & MEDIA DIGEST.....
Reuters news from around the world on Advertising, Marketing, the Media, the Internet, Brand-name Products and Consumer Trends ***********************************************
ADVERTISING AND MARKETING:
CHICAGO - McDonald's Corp says its advertising expenses totaled $503.3 million in 1996, up from $431.0 million in 1995 and $385.6 million in 1994.

CINCINNATI, Ohio - Procter & Gamble Co says it is assigning advertising responsibility for its Ivory personal cleansing brand in North America to Grey Advertising Inc, effective immediately. Grey replaces Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising.

CHICAGO - Triarc Cos Inc plans to apply the same marketing principles to Snapple that it used to turn around the Mistic beverage line, says Triarc Beverage Group chief executive Michael Weinstein. Edgy advertising, careful attention to distributor relationships, colorful labelling and a focus on cold-bottle street sales comprised Triarc's successful formula for Mistic and will set the tune for Snapple, too, he says.
LONDON - Mobile phone operator Vodafone Group Plc is to sponsor the English cricket team from 1998 in a four-year deal costing it 13 million stg ($21.3 million).

NEW YORK - The National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus Inc says Anheuser-Busch Cos Inc has agreed to stop advertising claims about Samuel Adams beer found to be unsupported. Boston Beer Co Inc, brewer of Samuel Adams beers, challenged the truthfulness and accuracy of Anheuser-Busch's advertising.

WASHINGTON - Federal Trade Commission Chairman Robert Pitofsky says a renewed investigation into R.J. Reynolds "Joe Camel" campaign may open the door to a broader investigation of tobacco advertising. In an appearance on Court TV telecast over the weekend, Pitofsky said the FTC is investigating whether there is new evidence against the "Joe Camel" campaign, which critics assert attracts underage smokers.
MEDIA AND THE INTERNET:

LONDON - Channel 5, Britain's new commercial television station, says it was delighted with its launch after initial figures showed that five of its first-night shows attracted a million viewers or more.
Initial figures from the BARB monitoring service give Channel 5 a 5.8 percent share of viewing in the 6 p.m. to 10.30 p.m. slot.

SEATTLE - A Microsoft Corp executive denies an industry report that the software giant's high-end Windows NT operating system was vulnerable to a new password-cracking code being circulated on the Internet. EE Times Online, the online version of a weekly CMP Media Inc trade newspaper, reported the code could enable a user to unscramble a list of passwords on a computer hard drive from a remote location.
NEW YORK - Walt Disney Co unit ABC News and Discovery Channel say they will begin airing a news program this Friday that is devoted exclusively to science.
WASHINGTON- In a major victory for television broadcasters, the Supreme Court has upheld a federal law forcing cable-TV operators around the country to carry local TV station broadcasts.
BRAND-NAME PRODUCTS AND MARKETS:

MILAN - Italian luxury goods company Gucci Group NV continued its financial renaissance, reporting that annual net profits more than doubled and it looked forward to further growth. Net profits for the twelve months to end-January 1997 rose to $168.4 million from $82.9 million on net sales up 76.1 percent to $880.7 million after $500.1 million.

ATLANTA - Coca-Cola Co says it expects its worldwide unit case volume to increase by 7.0 to 8.0 percent in the first quarter. It says worldwide gallon sales are expected to increase by 5.0 to 6.0 percent.
One unit case is equal to 24 eight-ounce servings, according to a Coca-Cola spokeswoman.

LONDON - Britain's supermarkets could hold 20 percent of the retail market for music and video products by the year 2000 compared with the current level of around 15 percent, according to the "UK Retail Report". Supermarkets are selling over 400 million stg of music and video products per year in a total market of 2.9 billion stg, the report says.

PARIS - Count Alexandre de Lur Saluces wins the first round of a court battle to block the huge luxury goods conglomerate LVMH from taking over the famed Chateau d'Yquem vineyard held by his family since 1785. A court in the southern city of Bordeaux blocked the sale of the property to LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton and rejected its request for a mediator but agreed to freeze the assets until the dispute is resolved.

PARIS - French tobacco company Seita says profits jumped 15 percent last year, powered by robust export performance, cost cutting and strong investment returns. The newly privatised company, best known for its pungent Gauloises and Gitanes cigarettes, said net attributable profit rose to 786 million francs ($139.7 million) from 684 million francs in 1995. But the company warned it was worried about prices in 1997.
CONSUMER TRENDS:

TOKYO - Japanese theme park operator Oriental Land Co Ltd says a total of 17.4 million people visited its Tokyo Disneyland theme park in the year ended March 31, up from 17.0 million in 1995/96. The company expects the number of visitors in the 1997/98 year, which started on Tuesday, will at least exceed 17 million, a company spokesman said.

TOKYO - Japanese consumers did some last-minute buying ahead of a Tuesday increase in the national sales tax, but there was no stampede to the stores and most people seemed to shrug off the higher tax burden. The consumption tax rises to five percent from three percent at the beginning of the new fiscal year as part of an attempt to reduce the massive government budget deficit.
